user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_set_connection_value_n:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN enum MHD_Result
MHD_set_connection_value_n (struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                            enum MHD_ValueKind kind,
                            const char *key,
                            size_t key_size,
                            const char *value,
                            size_t value_size)
{
  if ( (MHD_GET_ARGUMENT_KIND != kind) &&
       ( ((key ? strlen (key) : 0) != key_size) ||
         ((value ? strlen (value) : 0) != value_size) ) )
    return MHD_NO; /* binary zero is allowed only in GET arguments */

  return MHD_set_connection_value_n_nocheck_ (connection,
                                              kind,
                                              key,
                                              key_size,
                                              value,
                                              value_size);
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function MHD_set_connection_value_n:
static enum MHD_Result
connection_add_header (void *cls,
                       const char *key,
                       size_t key_size,
                       const char *value,
                       size_t value_size,
                       enum MHD_ValueKind kind)
{
  struct MHD_Connection *connection = (struct MHD_Connection *) cls;
  if (MHD_NO ==
      MHD_set_connection_value_n (connection,
                                  kind,
                                  key,
                                  key_size,
                                  value,
                                  value_size))
  {
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
    MHD_DLOG (connection->daemon,
              _ ("Not enough memory in pool to allocate header record!\n"));
#endif
    transmit_error_response_static (connection,
                                    MHD_HTTP_REQUEST_HEADER_FIELDS_TOO_LARGE,
                                    ERR_MSG_REQUEST_TOO_BIG);
    return MHD_NO;
  }
  return MHD_YES;
}
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
if ( (MHD_GET_ARGUMENT_KIND != kind) &&
     ( ((key ? strlen (key) : 0) != key_size) ||
       ((value ? strlen (value) : 0) != value_size) ) )
  return MHD_NO; /* binary zero is allowed only in GET arguments */
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation. The return statement is reached at runtime when kind != MHD_GET_ARGUMENT_KIND and either strlen(key) != key_size or strlen(value) != value_size; none of those sub-expressions is a compile-time constant in the shown code, so the branch is not provably unreachable. (A rule 2.1 violation would occur only if the whole conditional were provably constant — for example if the expression could be determined at compile time to be always false or always true for all calls, making the return or the subsequent call unreachable.)
